title-group.article-title: Screening of SLC26A4, FOXI1, KCNJ10, and GJB2 in Bilateral Deafness Patients with Inner Ear Malformation

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Otorhinolaryngology, the First Affiliated Hospital, Sun Yat-Sen University and Institute of Otorhinolaryngology, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, PR China

author-notes.corresp: Hongyan Jiang, MD, PhD, Otorhinolaryngology, Zhongshan Second Road, Guangzhou, 510080, China Email: hyjiangus@163.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © American Academy of Otolaryngology—Head and Neck Surgery Foundation 2012
permissions.copyright-holder: Official journal of the American Academy of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery Foundation

abstract.p: Objective. Bilateral nonsyndromic sensorineural hearing loss associated with inner ear malformation is closely related to genetics. SLC26A4 is considered to be the major involved gene. Recently, FOXI1 and KCNJ10 mutations have been linked to enlarged vestibular aqueducts and GJB2 mutations linked to temporal bone malformation. The authors aimed to investigate the mutation spectrums of these genes in Chinese patients with bilateral hearing impairment associated with inner ear malformation.
Setting. Affiliated hospital of the university.

Subjects and Methods. The authors analyzed the GJB2, SLC26A4, FOXI1, and KCNJ10 gene sequences in 43 patients presenting with bilateral hearing impairment associated with inner ear malformation using pyrosequencing and direct DNA sequencing.

Results. In total, 74.4% (32/43) of patients carried at least 1 of 14 pathogenic SLC26A4 mutations, including 6 novel mutations and 4 polymorphisms. Patients with enlarged vestibular aqueducts had a higher rate of SLC26A4 mutation than Mondini dysplasia patients. No FOXI1 or KCNJ10 potential pathogenic mutation was present, and GJB2 biallelic pathogenic mutations were uncommon (2.3%; 1/43). No significant correlation was observed between the genotype and phenotype of SLC26A4 mutations.

Conclusion. SLC26A4 accounts for 74.4% of inner ear malformations in our cohort, whereas FOXI1, KCNJ10, and GJB2 mutations are not common. Other possible genes or external factors may contribute to this multibranch abnormality.

body.p: Inner ear malformations such as enlarged vestibular aqueduct (EVA) and Mondini dysplasia are considered important pathologic changes that contribute to congenital hearing impairment. SLC26A4 is the major gene linked to EVA and Mondini dysplasia.1,2 The SLC26A4 gene has 21 exons, contains an open reading frame of 2343 base pairs, and has an extensive mutation map covering all exons and their flanking sequences. It is speculated that mutations in SLC26A4 induce EVA through influencing ionic fluid homeostasis in the inner ear.3 Although homozygous mutations are common, compound heterozygous mutations, previously considered to be pathogenic mutations responsible for EVA, represent a large part of the SLC26A4 mutation spectrum.4,5 The pathogenic mechanism of SLC26A4 compound heterozygous mutations is not fully understood, as functional analyses have not been completed.6 To date, more than 200 SLC26A4 mutations have been reported in different ethnic groups (indexed at www.healthcare.uiowa.edu/labs/pendredandbor/slcMutations.htm). IVS7-2A>G and c.2168A>G are the 2 most frequent mutations in Chinese patients7-9; however, SLC26A4 mutations are present in only 24% to 97.9% of patients depending on the ethnic origins of the population tested,10-13 implying that inner ear malformation is a multibranched disease.

FOXI1, the SLC26A4 transcriptional regulation factor, has been implicated in the development of inner ear abnormalities.13,14 FOXI1 mutations can lead to malformations raging from EVA to common cavity of the cochlea and vestibule in vivo.15 A FOXI1 mutation was first observed in a nonsyndromic patient with EVA carrying a double heterozygous SLC26A4/FOXI1 mutation.13 Similarly, the SLC26A4 functional partner KCNJ10 has been also implicated in nonsyndromic patients with EVA, with double heterozygous SLC26A4/KCNJ10 mutations reported in 2 individuals.14 Thus, FOXI1 and KCNJ10 may contribute to deafness and associated inner ear abnormalities. The FOXI1 gene was examined in Chinese patients, and no pathogenic mutation was found.16 KCNJ10 has not been reported in Chinese patients yet.

The exact interaction between GJB2 and temporal bone malformation remain unclear. Propst et al17 reported that temporal bone anomalies, including EVA, are common in GJB2-related hearing loss, whereas Kenna et al18 found that only 10% of biallelic GJB2 patients had abnormalities, mostly subtle, and none had EVA. Lee et al19 reported that patients who are wild type for GJB2 were more likely to have EVA than those with biallelic and heterozygous GJB2 mutations and concluded that temporal bone anomalies were uncommon in patients with GJB2 mutations.

The distribution and frequency of SLC26A4, FOXI1, KCNJ10, and GJB2 gene mutations in Chinese patients with inner ear malformations and bilateral hearing loss are not known. We selected patients with congenital bilateral hearing loss using the inner ear malformation classification of Sennaroglu and Saatci20 and investigated the mutation spectrum of SLC26A4, FOXI1, KCNJ10, and GJB2 in Chinese patients with bilateral hearing impairment associated with inner ear malformation in our outpatient department.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: Our cohort consisted of 43 sporadic or familial subjects mainly from southern China who attended our outpatient department between July 2010 and May 2011. The eligibility criterion was an inner ear malformation imaged by computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) associated with bilateral nonsyndromic sensorineural hearing loss. Inner ear malformations were defined using the classification of Sennaroglu and Saatci.20 The study was approved by the institutional review board of the First Affiliated Hospital, Sun Yat-sen University. Informed consent was obtained from all patients or their parents.

sec.title: Clinical Evaluation
sec.p: Each patient was evaluated with a complete medical history and physical examination to exclude the possibility of environmental causes. All patients underwent an otoscopic examination of the ear, nose, and throat and a general examination, with systematic assessment for signs of syndromic forms of deafness, in particular, goiter and hypothyroidism. Deaf patients underwent pure-tone audiometry or auditory brainstem response (ABR) and auditory steady-state response (ASSR). Air-conduction pure-tone average (ACPTA) thresholds in the conversational frequencies (0.5, 1, 2, and 4 kHz) were calculated and used to define the severity of deafness as mild (26-40 dB), moderate (41-70 dB), severe (70-90 dB), profound (90-119 dB), or anacusis (>120 dB). The severity of deafness was defined by the degree of hearing loss in the better ear. Hearing loss was considered progressive if the patient lost more than 8 dB in the ACPTA thresholds at conversational frequencies in 2 reliable audiometric tests carried out at least 5 years apart. Fluctuant deafness was defined when the mean hearing level at conversational frequencies increased by more than 10 dB between 2 successive audiograms.11

sec.title: Molecular Analyses
sec.p: Blood samples were collected from the subjects and DNA isolation was performed using a standard chloroform extraction method. Briefly, white blood cells were consecutively dissolved by sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) and protease K. Genomic DNA were then separated and purified by absolute ethanol after protein denaturalization by chloroform. The mean DNA A260/A280 ratio was 1.8 to 2.0. A molecular screening scheme was designed (Figure 1). First, exon 2 of GJB2 was screened in all patients using direct sequencing as previously described.21 Pyrosequencing was used to screen for the 2 common SLC26A4 gene mutations, IVS7-2A>G and c.2168A>G (detailed procedures have been previously described elsewhere22 and in Table 1). SLC26A4,23 FOXI1,13 and KCNJ10 14 were subsequently amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and directly sequenced using an ABI 3730 Genetic Sequencer (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, California), and all sequences were aligned and compared with the published sequences from the NCBI (GJB2: NG_008358.1; SLC26A4: NG_008489.1; FOXI1: NG_012068.1; KCNJ10: NG_016411.1).

caption.p: Diagram of the molecular screening scheme used for all patients.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Patient age, hearing loss onset, and hearing levels were reported as mean ± standard deviation values. The independent sample t test was used to compare hearing levels using SPSS 13.0 (SPSS, Inc, an IBM Company, Chicago, Illinois), and differences were considered significant if the P values were less than .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We recruited 43 patients (24 males and 19 females) from 3 multiplex and 37 simplex families, mainly from southern China. Patients were aged 1.3 to 37 years (7.02 ± 7.00 years). Their inner ear malformations included 34 EVA, 6 incomplete partition type II (IP-II, Mondini dysplasia), 1 incomplete partition type I (IP-I), 1 cochlear aplasia plus IP-II, and 1 cochlear hypoplasia. The onset of hearing loss ranged from birth to 72 months (17.3 ± 14.1 months). Head injury was the most common predisposing factor. Hearing evolution depended on the severity or type of inner ear malformation or external factors. Hearing levels varied from moderate to anacusis. No goiter was found within the cohort. All 43 patients were treated with cochlear implantation (23) or hearing aid (19) except 1 child, who was untreated.

Four types of GJB2 mutations, including 1 heterozygous c.109G>A mutation, 2 c.79G>A and c.341A>G polymorphisms, and a single heterogenic GJB2 homozygous c.109G>A mutation with a SLC26A4 compound heterozygous mutation (patient 10, Figure 2), were detected. No direct correlation was observed between GJB2 mutations and inner ear malformations. GJB2 biallelic pathogenic mutations were uncommon (2.3%; 1/43).

caption.p: Heterogenic mutations of GJB2 and SLC26A4 in patient 10 with an enlarged vestibular aqueduct. Genetic sequencing revealed a GJB2 homozygous 109G>A mutation and SLC26A4 compound heterozygous IVS7-2A>G and 2000T>C mutations.

sec.p: Using pyrosequencing, we detected bilateral SLC26A4 IVS7-2A>G and c.2168A>G mutations in 11 patients, which were confirmed by direct DNA sequencing (Figure 3).

caption.p: Pyrosequencing and DNA sequencing validation of SLC26A4 IVS7-2A>G homozygous mutation in patient 1 with enlarged vestibular aqueduct (A-C) and bilateral hearing loss detected by ABR (D). Pyrosequencing revealed an antisense homozygous IVS7-2T>C mutation (E), correlating with DNA sequencing (F).

sec.p: In the remainder of the patients (n = 32), the entire SLC26A4 coding sequence was subjected to DNA sequencing; another 17 patients were confirmed as carrying 2 pathologic mutations, and 4 patients carried a single pathologic mutation. In total, we found 4 SLC26A4 polymorphisms (IVS10+27C>A, IVS11+47T>C, IVS19-24T>A, IVS17-74G>A) and 14 SLC26A4 probable pathogenic mutations, including 8 known mutations (IVS7-A>G, IVS14-2A>G,24 c.1079C>T, c.1343C>T, c.754T>C, c.259G>T, c.2168A>G, and c.1229C>T) and 6 novel compound heterozygous mutations (c.2086C>T, c.2000T>C, c.413T>A, c.1691insA, c.1919G>A, and IVS13-1insC). There were 11 homozygous mutations (9 IVS7-2A>G, 1 c.2168A>G, 1 c.754T>C) and 17 compound heterozygous mutations. Among the 60 pathogenic alleles, including 28 patients with bialleles and 4 patients with a monoallele, IVS7-2A>G was the most common mutation, accounting for 58.3% (35/60; Table 2). Patients with EVA had a higher SLC26A4 mutation rate (85.3%; 29/34) than patients with IP-II (42.9%; 3/7), and taken together, 78.0% (32/41) of patients with EVA and IP-II carried a SLC26A4 mutation (Table 3).

caption.p: SLC26A4 Mutation Spectrums in Our Cohort of Chinese Patients with Inner Ear Malformations Associated with Hearing Loss

fn.p: There were 60 pathogenic alleles, including 28 patients with bialleles and 4 patients with a monoallele.

caption.p: Summary of SLC26A4 Gene Mutations in Patients with Different Inner Ear Malformations

fn.p: Abbreviations: EVA, enlarged vestibular aqueduct; IP-I, incomplete partition type I; IP-II, incomplete partition type II (Mondini deformity).

fn.label: a
fn.p: Patient 9 had separate IP-II and cochlear aplasia.

sec.p: Furthermore, the 15 patients who were all sporadic with 1 or no SLC26A4 mutation were screened for possible mutations in the FOXI1 and KCNJ10 coding sequences, and no pathogenic mutations were detected. FOXI1 c.1044T>C (p.Y348Y) was found in all 15 patients, and c.279G>A (p.R93R) was present in 6 patients. Only 1 patient carried a novel KCNJ10 c.1053C>T (p.D351D) heterozygous mutation.

In our cohort, 93.0% of patients suffered from bilateral severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss, and 7.0% of patients had moderate hearing impairment (Figure 4). Flat and downgraded audiograms were most common. As pure-tone audiometry (PTA) and ASSR adopt different hearing indexes (hearing level [HL] and sound pressure level [SpL]), we analyzed these results separately. Among the 18 patients taking the PTA test, the 13 patients with biallelic mutations averaged 87.94 ± 9.10 dB HL compared with 89.9 ± 23.0 dB HL in the 4 patients without biallelic mutations. The results of the 25 patients who underwent ASSR examination were compared, with average hearing levels of 93.58 ± 22.2 dB SpL in the 15 patients with biallelic mutations and 104.65 ± 13.4 dB SpL in the 10 patients without biallelic mutations. No significant differences in hearing levels were observed in either the PTA or ASSR results (P > .05; Table 4).

caption.p: Inner ear malformation SLC26A4 genotype-phenotype analysis.
SLC26A4 Genotype and Hearing Levels Comparison

fn.p: P values calculated from the data of “mean ± SD” in Biallele and Total in the same row using the Student t test. Abbreviations: ASSR, auditory steady-state response; HL, hearing level; PTA, pure-tone audiometry; SpL, sound pressure level.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our research indicated that SLC26A4 accounts for 74.4% (32/43) of inner ear malformations, with 78.0% (32/41) of patients with EVA and IP-II carrying at least 1 SLC26A4 mutation. Patients with EVA have a higher SLC26A4 mutation rate than patients with IP-II (85.3% vs 42.9%), implying that EVA is more likely to have a SLC26A4 genetic origin. A total of 14 potential pathogenic SLC26A4 mutations and 4 SLC26A4 polymorphisms were detected. IVS7-2A>G was most common, accounting for 58.3% of all pathologic mutations. We identified 6 novel SLC26A4 mutations to provide evidence in favor of the wide SLC26A4 mutation spectrum. These novel mutations, inherited separately from the probands’ parents with normal hearing, were all present in compound heterozygous states. This implies that alone, SLC26A4 heterozygous mutations are not sufficient to cause deafness.

A role for FOXI1 and KCNJ10 in deafness associated with EVA has been suggested by previous studies,13,14 but no pathogenic mutations were found in several subsequent studies.25 Our study did not find any potential pathogenic mutations in the FOXI1 and KCNJ10 genes. We found only 2 FOXI1 mutations—c.279G>A (p.R93R) and c.1044T>C (p.Y348Y)—and 1 KCNJ10 mutation, c.1053C>T (p.D351D), which does not lead to an amino acid change. These results are not in favor of a digenism between SLC26A4 and either FOXI1 or KCNJ10 in inner ear malformations. The FOXI1 and KCNJ10 genes may not be involved in our cohort because of the relatively small sample size; therefore, further large cohort studies are required to confirm the role of FOXI1 and KCNJ10 in inner ear malformations in Chinese patients.

The exact fundamental interaction of GJB2 with temporal bone malformations, including inner ear malformation, remains controversial. In this research, we attempted to investigate the intrinsic relationship between GJB2 and inner ear malformation. An intriguing heterogenic mutation was observed in patient 10 carrying GJB2 homozygous c.109G>A and SLC26A4 compound heterozygous IVS7-2A>G and c.2000T>C mutations. GJB2 homozygous c.109G>A was previously considered to be a pathogenic mutation causing moderate to profound deafness.26 Both SLC26A4 IVS7-2A>G and c.2000T>C are potential pathogenic mutations responsible for EVA; however, it is more likely to speculate that coincidental digenism occurs in this patient. We found other patients carrying GJB2 polymorphisms or heterozygous pathogenic mutations, which favors a theory of uncommon GJB2 biallelic pathogenic mutations in patients with inner ear malformations.

According to Hulander et al,15 inner ear malformations appear to lead to progressive degrees of changes in FOXI1 mutant mice, indicating that FOXI1 mutations may lead to different pathologic changes ranging from EVA to common cavity of the cochlea. Other genes, including SLC26A4, KCNJ10, FGF-3, and PAX2, participate in the functional control of normal inner ear development, indicating the genetic heterogeneity of inner ear malformation, prompting us to presume that other genes may be involved in the 25.6% (11/43) patients without SLC26A4, FOXI1, KCNJ10, or GJB2 mutations in our cohort.

In addition, the absence of SLC26A4, FOXI1, KCNJ10, or GJB2 mutations in patients with inner ear malformation could be explained by several factors. First, undetected SLC26A4, FOXI1, or KCNJ10 mutations could be present in these patients within active cryptic splice sites, introns, or the promoter region. Second, the specific nongenetic causes of inner ear malformation have not been fully identified. For example, congenital cytomegalovirus infection is a common nongenetic cause of hearing loss in children but accounts for few, if any, cases of EVA.27 In addition, the action of an environmental teratogen that disrupts normal inner ear development cannot be completely ruled out.

In this study, we adopted a pyrosequencing methodology to screen 2 frequent SLC26A4 mutations, IVS7-2A>G and c.2168A>G. Pyrosequencing has previously been used for screening procedures,22 and our results validate this approach. IVS7-2A>G and c.2168A>G contributed to 58.3% and 6.7% of all SLC26A4 mutations, indicating that a preferred screening for these alleles can facilitate the routine molecular analysis of SLC26A4 in Chinese patients. In fact, the IVS7-2A>G mutation is common in Eastern Asia, as several large cohort investigations have reported a high prevalence of IVS7-2A>G in the Chinese population (22.3%-64.6%).7-9,28 Haplotype and single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) analysis of IVS7-2A>G suggested that the mutation may originate from a common ancestor in Taiwanese individuals.29 In Koreans, IVS7-2A>G accounts for 20% of mutant SLC26A4 alleles and is the second most prevalent genetic variant after c.2168A>G.12 In Japanese individuals, IVS7-2A>G has a low incidence of approximately 3%, and c.2168A>G is the leading variant.10 Apart from IVS7-2A>G, the mutation spectrum of SLC26A4 is broad, with prevalent mutations extending from exon 3 to exon 19, indicting the necessity of sequencing all coding sequences of SLC26A4.

Aside from the mutation spectrum, the SLC26A4 allele mutation genotype (biallele, monoallele, or zero allele) did not relate to hearing levels in our results. As PTA and ASSR adopt different hearing indexes, we analyzed hearing results separately. This would reduce the group numbers but increase the comparability and reliability to reflect a genotype-phenotype relationship. Regarding the degree of deafness, 93.0% of the patients with SLC26A4 mutations suffered from severe to profound deafness involving the whole frequency, especially at high frequencies, corresponding to the pathophysiology of inner ear malformations. Further genotype and phenotype analysis of SLC26A4 mutations is recommended.

It is important to note that this research has some limitations. First, testing of a relatively larger cohort is necessary to testify the veracity of our results. Additional screening of the SLC26A4 promoter region may reveal additional information, as our strategy of direct sequencing of the coding sequences and adjacent intronic sequences may have missed some mutations. Furthermore, we could not perform haplotype analysis in patients with no or a single SLC26A4 mutant allele because of the lack of informative family subjects. The wide SLC26A4 mutation spectrums in these 15 patients also limited haplotype analysis.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This study indicates that SLC26A4 accounts for 74.4% of inner ear malformations in our cohort, whereas FOXI1, KCNJ10, and GJB2 mutations are not common, indicating that other genes or external factors may possibly contribute to this multibranch abnormality.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Kaitian Chen, study designation, patients’ data collection, experiment, and writing; Xianren Wang, designed and analyzed data and writing; Liang Sun, patients’ data collection, experiment, data analysis, and revising the article; Hongyan Jiang, whole experiment coordination, designation, and revising the article.
